DataElement.preferredName: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome Systemic Illness Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Value to represent the extent of the deficiency of cellular immunity caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) as characterized by the occurrence of systemic illness and changes in overall health.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome Systemic Illness Stage
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A syndrome resulting from the acquired deficiency of cellular immunity caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).  It is characterized by the reduction of the Helper T-lymphocytes in the peripheral blood and the lymph nodes.  Symptoms include generalized lymphadenopathy, fever, weight loss, and chronic diarrhea.  Patients with AIDS are especially susceptible to opportunistic infections (usually pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections, tuberculosis, candida infections, and cryptococcosis), and the development of malignant neoplasms (usually non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and Kaposi's sarcoma).  The human immunodeficiency virus is transmitted through sexual contact, sharing of contaminated needles, or transfusion of contaminated blood. -- 2004_Affecting an entire system._Of low value or worth._Of low value or worth._Health refers to a person's state of physical, mental and social well-being; usually it refers specifically to the state of being in good health, a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being, and does not consist only of the absence of disease or infirmity. In any organism health constitutes a form of homeostasis with inputs and outputs of energy and mass in approximate equilibrium allowing for growth and continued survival. In humans, a subjective feeling of well-being coming from somatic and cognitive perceptions is considered an essential component of health._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A syndrome resulting from the acquired deficiency of cellular immunity caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). It is characterized by the reduction of the Helper T-lymphocytes in the peripheral blood and the lymph nodes; opportunistic infections (usually pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections, tuberculosis, candida infections, and cryptococcosis); and the development of malignant neoplasms (usually non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and Kaposi's sarcoma). The human immunodeficiency virus is transmitted through sexual contact, sharing of contaminated needles, or transfusion of contaminated blood. Generalized lymphadenopathy, fever, weight loss, and chronic diarrhea are common symptoms of AIDS. The patients usually die either of opportunistic infections or malignant neoplasms. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A syndrome resulting from the acquired deficiency of cellular immunity caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). It is characterized by the reduction of the Helper T-lymphocytes in the peripheral blood and the lymph nodes. Symptoms include generalized lymphadenopathy, fever, weight loss, and chronic diarrhea. Patients with AIDS are especially susceptible to opportunistic infections, tuberculosis, candida infections, and cryptococcosis), and the development of malignant neoplasms (usually non-Hodgkin lymphoma and Kaposi sarcoma). The human immunodeficiency virus is transmitted through sexual contact, sharing of contaminated needles, or transfusion of contaminated blood.

Property.preferredDefinition: (sis-TEM-ik) Affecting the entire body.:Of low value or worth.:The state of the organism when it functions optimally without evidence of disease.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: Affecting an entire system.
Of low value or worth.

Refers to a person's state of physical, mental and social well-being; usually it refers specifically to the state of being in good health, a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being, and does not consist only of the absence of disease or infirmity. In any organism health constitutes a form of homeostasis with inputs and outputs of energy and mass in approximate equilibrium allowing for growth and continued survival. In humans, a subjective feeling of well-being coming from somatic and cognitive perceptions is considered an essential component of health.
The extent of a cancer in the body.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome Systemic Poor Health Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: An acquired defect in immune system function caused by human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).  AIDS is associated with increased susceptibility to certain cancers and to opportunistic infections, which are infections that occur rarely except in individuals with weak immune systems._Protected against infectious disease by either specific or non-specific mechanisms. (On-line Medical Dictionary)_The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body._Affecting an entire system._Of low value or worth._Health refers to a person's state of physical, mental and social well-being; usually it refers specifically to the state of being in good health, a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being, and does not consist only of the absence of disease or infirmity. In any organism health constitutes a form of homeostasis with inputs and outputs of energy and mass in approximate equilibrium allowing for growth and continued survival. In humans, a subjective feeling of well-being coming from somatic and cognitive perceptions is considered an essential component of health.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Features commonly associated with lymphoma, including fever above 38C, drenching night sweats, and weight loss of more than 10% of body mass in the previous 6 months.  B symptoms are signs of a poor prognosis in patients with lymphoma.: Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.: (sis-TEM-ik) Affecting the entire body.: Of low value or worth.: The state of the organism when it functions optimally without evidence of disease.: A malignant neoplasm characterized by a vascular proliferation which usually contains blunt endothelial cells. Erythrocyte extravasation and hemosiderin deposition are frequently present. The most frequent site of involvement is the skin however, it may also occur internally.  It generally develops in people with compromised immune systems including those with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS).

Concepts.definition: Features commonly associated with lymphoma, including fever above 38C, drenching night sweats, and weight loss of more than 10% of body mass in the previous 6 months.  B symptoms are signs of a poor prognosis in patients with lymphoma.
Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.
Affecting an entire system.
Of low value or worth.

Refers to a person's state of physical, mental and social well-being; usually it refers specifically to the state of being in good health, a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being, and does not consist only of the absence of disease or infirmity. In any organism health constitutes a form of homeostasis with inputs and outputs of energy and mass in approximate equilibrium allowing for growth and continued survival. In humans, a subjective feeling of well-being coming from somatic and cognitive perceptions is considered an essential component of health.

A malignant neoplasm characterized by a vascular proliferation which usually contains blunt endothelial cells. Erythrocyte extravasation and hemosiderin deposition are frequently present. The most frequent site of involvement is the skin; however it may also occur internally. It generally develops in people with compromised immune systems including those with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS).

PermissibleValues.value: S1 - History of OIs and/or thrush
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: S1 - History of OIs and/or thrush

ValueMeaning.preferredName: S1 - History of OIs and/or thrush
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The aggregate of past events; the continuum of events occurring in succession leading from the past to the present; a record or narrative description of past events.: An infection caused by an organism which becomes pathogenic under certain conditions, e.g., during immunosuppression.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.: A condition in which Candida albicans, a type of yeast, grows out of control in moist skin areas of the body. It is usually a result of a weakened immune system, but can be a side effect of chemotherapy or treatment with antibiotics. Thrush usually affects the mouth (oral thrush); however, rarely, it spreads throughout the entire body.: A malignant neoplasm characterized by a vascular proliferation which usually contains blunt endothelial cells. Erythrocyte extravasation and hemosiderin deposition are frequently present. The most frequent site of involvement is the skin however, it may also occur internally.  It generally develops in people with compromised immune systems including those with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS).

Concepts.definition: The aggregate of past events; the continuum of events occurring in succession leading from the past to the present; a record or narrative description of past events.
Infection caused by an organism that is capable of causing disease in immunocompromised patients only (e.g. HIV-positive or transplanted patients).--2004
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
Infection with the organism Candida.

A malignant neoplasm characterized by a vascular proliferation which usually contains blunt endothelial cells. Erythrocyte extravasation and hemosiderin deposition are frequently present. The most frequent site of involvement is the skin; however it may also occur internally. It generally develops in people with compromised immune systems including those with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS).

PermissibleValues.value: S1 - Other HIV-related illness (e.g., neurological disease or lymphoma)
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: S1 - Other HIV-related illness (e.g., neurological disease or lymphoma)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: S1 - Other HIV-related illness (e.g., neurological disease or lymphoma)
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: any state accompanied by evidence of HIV in the body (positive test for HIV genome, cDNA, proteins, antigens, or antibodies); may be medically asymptomatic or symptomatic; prefer AIDS when appropriate.: Related; connected or associated.: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.: A malignant neoplasm characterized by a vascular proliferation which usually contains blunt endothelial cells. Erythrocyte extravasation and hemosiderin deposition are frequently present. The most frequent site of involvement is the skin however, it may also occur internally.  It generally develops in people with compromised immune systems including those with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS).

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
An infection caused by the human immunodeficiency virus.
A state of connectedness between people, objects, or events; to be associated or connected with something.

Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

A malignant neoplasm characterized by a vascular proliferation which usually contains blunt endothelial cells. Erythrocyte extravasation and hemosiderin deposition are frequently present. The most frequent site of involvement is the skin; however it may also occur internally. It generally develops in people with compromised immune systems including those with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Karnofsky Performance Status. A standard way of measuring the ability of cancer patients to perform ordinary tasks.  The scores range from 0 to 100, with a higher score indicating a better ability to carry out daily activities.  KPS may be used to determine a patient's prognosis, to measure changes in functioning, or to decide if a patient could be included in a clinical trial.: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that an object of interest is smaller than another object in quantity or measure or value or status.: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::70: A malignant neoplasm characterized by a vascular proliferation which usually contains blunt endothelial cells. Erythrocyte extravasation and hemosiderin deposition are frequently present. The most frequent site of involvement is the skin however, it may also occur internally.  It generally develops in people with compromised immune systems including those with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS).

Concepts.definition: An index designed for classifying patients 16 years of age or older by their functional impairment.
A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that an object of interest is smaller than another object in quantity or measure or value or status.
A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.

A malignant neoplasm characterized by a vascular proliferation which usually contains blunt endothelial cells. Erythrocyte extravasation and hemosiderin deposition are frequently present. The most frequent site of involvement is the skin; however it may also occur internally. It generally develops in people with compromised immune systems including those with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS).
